htmlTroubleshooting:
Condenser Troubleshooting Guidelines

Introduction

The following guidelines will focus on the Dashboard KPIs highlighted below, which is taken from Condenser Efficiency Modeling Aug 26, 2020 Rev2:

Troubleshooting

It is important to note that all of the troubleshooting in dicators highlighted below start with the plant noticing one thing an increase in Condenser Operating Back Pressure (BP). This is the actual BP at which the condenser is currently operating. The board operator notices their condenser pressure is elevated, they bring that to their boss, and their boss calls the ChemTreat representative, starting the troubleshooting process.

It is important to note that the BP can rise without a true condenser performance issue. For instance, with an increase in ambient temperatures comes an increase cooling water supply temperature. As the inlet water temperature rises, so does the operating BP – not exactly a performance issue, just a fact of physics. Also, if the plant is running very hard and sending more steam to the condenser than designed, the operating BP will rise – again, not a performance issue, just a fact of physics. This is where the ChemTreat representative can do a very quick determination as to whether or not there is a real condenser performance issue. If there have been no atmospheric anomalies and the plant is not doing anything out of the ordinary as far asoperations, the ChemTreat representative should then start the troubleshooting process with BP Deviation Overall.

BP Deviation Overall

The BP Deviation Overall is a very complicated calculation that takes many factors into consideration. If the BP Deviation Overall is > 0, then there is in fact an issue with the overallcondenser operation. It is very important to note that the BP Deviation Overall takes everything into consideration, not just the condenser. For instance, if the cooling water pumps are pumpingless water through the condenser, that is not exactly a condenser related issue, but it manifests inthe condenser. The BP Deviation Condenser Only highlights issues directly related to thecondenser, i.e. condenser tube fouling, air binding, etc. If the BP Deviation Overall is > 0, it is time to start troubleshooting the specifics of the condenser performance data. This starts with TRand TTD Deviations, as they will guide you to the right spot 99% of the time.

Shift in TR Deviation Only

Temperature Rise (TR) is calculated using the following:

TR (°F)= CWout Temp-CWin Temp

TR tells us how much heat was picked up per pound of water, as it takes 1 btu to raise 1 lb of water 1°F. If the TR rises, it is for one of two reasons: An increase in heat duty (i.e. steam loading) or A decrease in cooling water flow (i.e. pump problems, strainers plugged, etc.). If theTR decreases, it is for one of two reasons: A decrease in heat duty (i.e. steam loading) or Anincrease in cooling water flow (i.e. pump improvements, cleaning screens, etc.).

A shift in TR is typically due to either a shift in steam load (i.e. plant production) or cooling water flow. If it has been confirmed the plant is not swinging in load, and there is a shift in TRonly, it typically means there is a flow related issue/improvement and you should look at thefollowing:

  • Does calculated cooling water flow confirm a shift in flow rates?
  • Have the circ water pump discharge pressures changed?
  • Have the circ water pump amps changed?
  • Have there been circ pump issues or repairs?
  • If Delta P is monitored, has it shifted?
  • Is the cooling water system equipped with strainers? Have they become obstructed orrecently cleaned?
  • Have the circ water pump screens become obstructed or recently cleaned?
  • Has the turbidity shifted in the bulk cooling water?
  • Has the shift in TR been gradual or sharp? A gradual change typically is related to cooling water flow as it pertains to water chemistry. For instance, a gradual rise in TR could be due to a screen or strainer becoming fouled with biological growth, which happens over time. A sharp rise in TR could be something mechanical related to a circ water pump.
  • If it is a once through system, is the air evacuator pump on the exit water box in operation? These water boxes can build up air pockets thus reducing flow through thecondenser.

It is important to focus on flow and load related issues/improvements when troubleshooting TR-only related issues.

Shift in TTD Deviation Only

Terminal Temperature Difference (TTD), also called Approach Temperature sometimes, is calculated using the following equation:

TTD (°F)=Steam Temp-CWout Temp

TTD tells us how efficiently the heat was transferred from the steam side to the water side.

The TTD can be affected by many things, all of which look very similar, if not the same, whene xamining the data. For instance, biological fouling, scaling, silt accumulation, and air bindingon the shell side, all cause the TTD to increase, and all look the same when looking at the KPIs.Where a TR-only shift indicates a condenser-tube-flow-related related change, a TTD-only shiftindicates a condenser-tube-surface related change (i.e. air, silt, bio, scale). When troubleshootinga TTD-only shift, you should look at the following:

  • Has there been a shift in cooling water chemistry – loss of pH control, increase inturbidity, loss of polymer or dispersant feed, loss of biocide feed?
  • Has there been a shift in the makeup water quality? TSS increase? Temperature? pH?
  • Have there been air in-leakage issues/improvements? As there been any recent work onthe air-removal systems (i.e.vacuum pumps).Air in-leakage usually goes unidentifieduntil there is an issue in the condenser back pressure.This is usually the hardest to identify since many do not monitor air in-leakage online. Has the condensate Dissolved Oxygen (DO) changed? Has the condensate Cation Conductivity (CC) changed? The DO and CC are excellent surrogates for air in-leakage and are typically readily available.
  • Is the shift in TTD gradual or sharp? A sharp change typically indicates a mechanicalissue like air in-leakage. A gradual shift typically indicates a water chemistry change. This is not always the case, but experience has proven this time and time again.

When troubleshooting a TTD-only issue, remember, bio, silt, scale, and air all look the same when examining condenser performance data. This is a time when all parts of the operation need to be examined – water treatment chemistry, condensate chemistry, makeup water chemistry, andair removal system operations.

Shift in both TR and TTD Deviation

When there is a shift in both the TR and TTD Deviations,it is an indication of macro fouling. Macro fouling is when a larger item, such as a clam shell or piece of cooling tower fill partially obstructs the inlet of a condenser tube. This causes a reduction of flow through that tube, which in turn causes an increase in the local TR as well as increase in the exiting water temperature. Most condensers do not macro foul all tubes, at least not immediately. Therefore, there are cleantubes that do not see an increase in the exit water temperature. This phenomenon leads to an increase in TTD as well.

Some questions to ask when troubleshooting macro fouling:

  • Does the plant have a history with macro organism fouling such as zebra mussels? Is itthat time of year?
  • Has the cooling tower basin, or once-through intake areas, become loaded with sediment? TSS tends to accumulate in the tower basins and once-through intake areas can see rising levels of sediment with shifting lake or river levels.
  • Is the cooling tower fill intact? Many believe the circ pump intake screens will block large items from entering the condenser water box. Experience has shown this is a poor assumption.
htmlTroubleshooting1:
Basic TR and TTD Deviation Guidelines

The following illustration is a quick reference guide to what is to be discussed below when it comes to TTD and TD Deviations:

What is important here is that noticing the difference between a TTD-only, TR-only, TTD/TR-combined shift is critical to effective troubleshooting or confirming changes with improvements.to be examined – water treatment chemistry, condensate chemistry, makeup water chemistry, and

Production Deviation Overall

Production Deviation Overall is calculated using the BP Deviation Overall. It takes the Btu content of the BP deviation and converts it to a MWhr deviation. This is a theoretical calculation, but it has proven to be very accurate. Troubleshooting Production Deviation Overall starts with troubleshooting BP Deviation Overall.

MW $$$ Lost/Day

MW $$$ Lost/Day is calculated using Production Deviation Overall, which has the unit of measure MWhrs. Therefore, MM $$$ Lost/Day is calculated using the following equation:

(MW $$$ Lost)/Day=Production Devation Overall*$$$/MWhr*24
Troubleshooting MW $$$ Lost/Day starts with troubleshooting Production Deviation Overall, which in turn starts with BP Deviation Overall.

Heat Rate Deviation Overall

Heat Rate Deviation Overall is calculated using the BP Deviation Overall. It uses EPRI guidelines regarding % efficiency lost per 1 inHg BP Deviation. This calculation has proven to be very accurate. Troubleshooting Heat Rate Deviation Overall starts with troubleshooting BP Deviation Overall.

Est Excess Fuel Burned Overall

Est Excess Fuel Burned Overall is calculated using the BP Deviation Overall. It takes the Btucontent of the BP deviation and converts it to a Btu deviation. From that Btu deviation, thecalculation uses the plant’s typical heat rate, which is also the efficiency, to determine the amount of fuel needed to replace the Btus lost in the calculated deviation. This is a theoretical calculation uses the plant’s typical heat rate, which is also the efficiency, to determine theOverall starts with troubleshooting BP Deviation Overall.

Est Excess Fuel $$$ Overall

Est Excess Fuel $$$ Overall is calculated using the Est Excess Fuel Burned Overall. It takes theBtu content of the Est Excess Fuel Burned Overall and multiplies it by the cost of the fuel used.The Est Excess Fuel Burned Overall is in btu/hr, so Est Excess Fuel $$$ Overall takes that value and multiplies it by 24 for $$$/day. Troubleshooting Est Excess Fuel $$$ Overall starts with troubleshooting BP Deviation Overall.

Est Excess CO2 Emissions Overall

Est Excess CO2 Emissions Overall is calculated by converting the BP Deviation Overall to a Btu penalty, which is then converted to a fuel penalty. The CO2 produced per 1,000,000 Btus of fuel burned is known for all types of fuels used in power generation. This number is multiplied by the fuel penalty to get the total Est Excess CO2 Emissions Overall. Troubleshooting Est Excess CO2 Emissions Overall starts with troubleshooting BP Deviation Overall.
executiveSummary: This report should be reviewed with your ChemTreat account representative. Results are derived via analysis of plant parameters and may vary dependent on quality of these parameters as well as other unforeseen variables.
